BBProbDef1: ^At work, I solve difficult problems all the time. But when it comes to the challenges I’m facing in my personal life, I get stuck.
BBProbDef2: ^It doesn’t seem like there are any good options.
BBProbDef3: ^I try to make plans for myself but something urgent always comes up at work or with the kids.
BBProbDef4: ^Then I end up frustrated at home, and feeling guilty for being frustrated!
BBProbDef5: ^I know I need to make time to pursue my own interests and make connections in my community.
BBProbDef6: ^At first, my goal was to finish my poetry book by the end of the year, but visualizing all that work made me feel overwhelmed.
BBProbDef7: ^So, I’ve decided to break it down into more manageable parts.
BBProbDef8: ^There are some big obstacles that make it hard for me to reach these goals.
BBProbDef9: ^I know I won’t be able to overcome any of these obstacles overnight.
BBProbDef10: ^But now that I’ve been able to get them out of my head and into my journal, they don’t seem so impossible.
BowenProbDef1: ^I’m not usually the kind of person who can sit still and think about an issue. I like to be doing something.
BowenProbDef2: ^But in the past, I always knew what I was aiming for. I can’t just work harder in this situation; I have to work smarter.
BowenProbDef3: ^The visualization helped me sort the facts of the situation, what I would change about it, and see which challenge is the priority right now - our rocky finances.
BowenProbDef4: ^When I really dig into it, that’s the root of a lot of my other frustrations – arguments with my wife, stress at work, and uncertainty about the future.
BowenProbDef5: ^Honing in on the problem made it easier to picture the "final destination" - the place I want to get to.
BowenProbDef6: ^I thought it would be easy to think of the obstacles that are keeping me from getting to that final destination. I’ve been up against them for a while now.
BowenProbDef7: ^But when I focus on the facts, I can see one obstacle I missed - that I didn’t have all of the information I need to make the right decision. Once I add that, my list of obstacles is:
BowenProbDef8: ^This is a new kind of problem for me. When I first moved to the U.S. and started a business, it was hard, but I liked the challenge and I was confident.
BowenProbDef9: ^This time is different. My wife and son are depending on me, and time and resources are a lot tighter.
BowenProbDef10: ^Setting a solid goal is a good first step – now that I know the destination, I can start mapping out the route.
JenProbDef1: ^I’ve been struggling with focusing on accepting myself for who I am, rather than comparing myself to others or feeling like I’m not living up to others’ expectations.
JenProbDef2: ^I find myself thinking that if I could just change some part of my appearance, or if my parents would really listen to me or be more accepting of my queerness, that I would be able to feel confident in myself.
JenProbDef3: ^But when I think about what I really want right now, it’s to change the way I see myself – not change something about myself.
JenProbDef4: ^I know this isn't the type of problem that can be "fixed" by focusing on what's outside of my control. At the heart of it, I have to work on my thoughts and feelings.
JenProbDef5: ^t was hard at first to separate the facts about my negative thinking from the reality. So I approached my situation like a scientist looking for facts. This really helped me see my obstacles more clearly.
JenProbDef6: ^Being clear about the problem I’m facing makes it seem less overwhelming.
JenProbDef7: ^Looking at my problem definition, I can see that many of my past attempts to decrease my insecurities have been working on the wrong problem – changing something about myself rather than accepting myself.
